text:
I asked this over in <#C6A044SQH|helpdesk> but didn’t get any responses so thought I’d try my luck in here…
I’m trying to import a file into a DataFrame using CSV.File. I have the following txt file:
```Date, Time, Colour
2019/7/21, 14:40:15, red
2019/7/22, 14:40:15.001, yellow
2019/7/23, 14:40:15.002, green```
I can’t import this file using the below Julia code. However, I can if I change the type for column 2 to ‘string’ instead of ‘time’. It seems that I can’t set the type for column 2 to ‘time’ because I’m using a custom Dates.DateFormat for column 1.
When I don’t specify any types for each column Julia automatically correctly applies the ‘time’ type to column 2 (and ‘string’ to column 1 which I don’t want).
How can I fix this? Is it possible to specify two custom Dates.DateFormat?
```using CSV, Dates, DataFrames

filetypes = Dict(
    1 => Date,
    2 => Time,
    3 => String,
    );

filedate = Dates.DateFormat("y/m/d");

df = DataFrame(CSV.File("file.txt"; header=1, delim=',', dateformat=filedate, types=filetypes))```

elements.text:
but didn’t get any responses so thought I’d try my luck in here…
I’m trying to import a file into a DataFrame using CSV.File. I have the following txt file:

I can’t import this file using the below Julia code. However, I can if I change the type for column 2 to ‘string’ instead of ‘time’. It seems that I can’t set the type for column 2 to ‘time’ because I’m using a custom Dates.DateFormat for column 1.
When I don’t specify any types for each column Julia automatically correctly applies the ‘time’ type to column 2 (and ‘string’ to column 1 which I don’t want).
How can I fix this? Is it possible to specify two custom Dates.DateFormat?

text: You can pass a `Dict` to the `dateformats` (note the plural) keyword argument that's of the same form as your `filetypes`: a mapping of column indices to date formats.

elements.text: (note the plural) keyword argument that's of the same form as your
: a mapping of column indices to date formats.
